text: was a after Tenroku and before Jōgen. This period started in December 973 and ended in July 976.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Ten'en" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 958. The reigning emperor were .Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du japon, pp. 144-146; Brown, Delmer et al. (1979). Gukanshō, p. 299-300; Varely, H. Paul. (1980). Jinnō Shōtōki, pp. 191-192. ==Events of the Ten'en era== * 28 May 973 (Ten'en 1, 24th day of the 4th month): A fire broke out in a Minamoto compound located near the Imperial Palace. The fire destroyed more than 300 houses. The guard was doubled around the Emperor's residence.Titsingh, p. 145. * 974 (Ten'en 2, 2nd month): Fujiwara no Kanemichi was named daijō-daijin in the Imperial court hierarchy; and he was given permission to travel to court in a carriage. * 974 (Ten'en 2, 10th month): The emperor received a gift of horses from Korea. * 975 (Ten'en 3, 8th month): A comet was seen in the night sky. ==Related pages== * Heian period ==References== ==Other websites== * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection Ten'en 1st 2nd 3rd 4th 973 974 975 976 Preceded by: Tenroku Era or nengō: Ten'en Succeeded by: Jōgen Category:Japanese eras
title: Ten'en
